road.description:
A public road primarily intended for automobile travel.

Sidewalk and bikeway edges can be represented as part of a road edge using the left/right/both modifiers. See the GATIS Playbook for more information.

sidewalk.description:
A designated pedestrian path along the side of a roadway.

This edge type includes roadway pedestrian lanes, in which a section of the roadway surface is divided out for pedestrian use. 

The easiest way to model these pedestrian lanes that follow a roadway is as an attribute on the roadway ("left/right/both"); where the geometry diverges and you wish to model that diversion, create an edge that models the diverged path and associate it with the road with the pedestrian_lane attribute.

curb_ramp_toplanding.description:
An edge that represents the transition area from sidewalk space to a curb ramp (curb_ramp_runslope). This area is sometimes called a "top landing" or "turning area." It represents the area where a user would likely stand or wait to be seen by vehicles while crossing or waiting to cross, or the place to stand to signal their intent to cross where crossing signals may not exist. 

See the Playbook https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1NJIyzpRFZYbStU7Esa5gB3ZS8yMq78rL/edit?slide=id.g3ae97a94198_1_7#slide=id.g3ae97a94198_1_7 for guidance and examples.

curb_ramp_runslope.description:
An edge that represents the sloped surface (curb ramp) that aids a user in transitioning from the sidewalk space down to the street level for crossing, where a curb cut exists. 

See the Playbook https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1NJIyzpRFZYbStU7Esa5gB3ZS8yMq78rL/edit?slide=id.g3ae97a94198_1_7#slide=id.g3ae97a94198_1_7 for guidance and examples.

footway.description: A dedicated pedestrian path/route that does not fall into another category. Some common examples of footways include pedestrian routes at outdoor venues or in outdoor spaces (shopping center lots, campuses, parks, sports fields, etc.), alleyways that don’t appear within the road network, and official connector paths (for example, near freeway ramps or other infrastructure). May be used to map data from OpenStreetMap with their “footway” tag that does not align well with another GATIS edge type; see the Playbook for more details.

crossing.description: A location where infrastructure or a designation exists to help pedestrians and/or cyclists cross motor vehicle traffic lanes or other areas designated for traffic. In many locations, a crossing is a crosswalk.

ramp.description: Indicates any type of ramp, other than a curb ramp, where the footway is built to deliberately slope up or down to improve access. In Tiers 1 and 2, use the curb_ramp node to indicate curb ramps; in Tiers 3+, use the curb_ramp_runslope edge.

traffic_island.description: A median or other raised or protected area between traffic lanes on the road surface, sometimes meant to provide a safe space for pedestrians to stop. A traffic island may or may not have a midblock entrance. Can be used to indicate transit islands.

steps.description:
Fixed steps or stairs that appear along a pedestrian way. 

GATIS maps outdoor infrastructure; switch to GTFS Pathways or IMDF conventions for indoor infrastructure.

elevator.description:
Elevators, funiculars, or other car- or enclosure-based constructions meant to vertically carry a pedestrian from one level of physical infrastructure to another. 

GATIS maps outdoor infrastructure; switch to GTFS Pathways or IMDF conventions for indoor infrastructure.

escalator.description:
Escalators or any other construction of moving stairs meant to carry a pedestrian from one level of physical infrastructure to another. 

GATIS maps outdoor infrastructure; switch to GTFS Pathways or IMDF conventions for indoor infrastructure.

bikeway.description:
A designated cycling lane or path that can be on, next to or away from a road.

If pedestrians may also use the path, use multi_use_path edge instead.

multi_use_path.description: A path that allows more than one use (i.e. bike and pedestrian travel or pedestrian and equestrian travel). A multi-use path is likely to be a formal or official path, may be paved or have a constructed surface, and may contain infrastructure such as signage or buffer zones. Compared to a "trail," its surface is generally more level, wider and meant to be accessible to a range of users. Some transportation guides use the term "shared use paths" rather than "multi-use paths"; within GATIS both would be categorized with the multi_use_path edge.

trail.description: Any kind of path or trail that allows bicycle and/or pedestrian travel that does not fall into the multi_use_path designation. Includes official and unofficial unpaved trails, social trails, goatpaths and desire lines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desire_path).

attributes.name: edge_id
attributes.description:
A unique identifier for the edge. 

[NOTE: We will fill in instructions here on how to generate IDs, and we will also provide a data validator that may be capable of validating and helping to fill in these IDs.]

attributes.name: reference_ids
attributes.description: Can be used to add reference IDs to other data sources such as OSM, Overture, ARNOLD, HMPS, TIGER, Census road network, etc.). Should be an array of JSONs with the source name and ID pair. Each JSON should contain an ID field and source field at minimum.

attributes.name: street_name
attributes.description: Specifies the name of a road associated with the edge, such as the street along which a sidewalk or cycleway runs. In many cases, routing engines can fill in the closest street name for travelers to see. Use this attribute to specify the associated street explicitly or to correct an error within routing engines.

attributes.name: facility_name
attributes.description: The common or official name for this edge, by which travelers might recognize it. The same facility_name may be used for multiple edges, such as segments that make up a longer distance multi-use path with a name (ex. "Atlanta BeltLine").
attributes.example: "Atlanta Beltline", "Washington and Old Dominion Trail", "Minutemen Bikeway", "Lenape Trail", "East Coast Greenway"

attributes.name: curb_ramp_system_id
attributes.description:
An identifier to link any nodes and edges that are involved in the same "curb ramp system," which is the network of elements that sidewalk users use to transition from a sidewalk to a crossing. 

This may include sidewalk edges, curb_ramp_toplanding, curb_ramp_runslope, and crosswalk edges, as well as sidewalk_to_ramp, bottom_of_ramp or generic nodes.

attributes.name: edge_type
attributes.description: Indicates the type of edge.

attributes.name: from_node
attributes.description: This attribute is used to identify the node where an edge begins, using the node_id attribute on the nodes table. This information is needed for routing via metadata but is optional for data designed to be routed via fully connected geospatial data.

attributes.name: to_node
attributes.description: This attribute is used to identify the node where an edge ends, using the node_id attribute on the nodes table. This information is needed for routing via metadata but is optional for data designed to be routed via fully connected geospatial data.

attributes.name: directionality
attributes.description: Specifies the directionality of the edge. If the edge is bidirectional, choose “both.” Used to help identify when bicycle infrastructure allows traffic in both directions. If left blank, "both" is assumed. See the Playbook for a fuller explanation of the directionality of geometric linework and how different GATIS attributes relate.

attributes.name: width_in
attributes.description: Average or typical width of the edge. Measured in inches and rounded to the nearest inch. Cannot be negative. Use width_tolerance_in to describe the variance in the width along this edge. If the width changes substantially, the edge should be segmented into multiple edges with differing width_in values.

attributes.name: height_max_passable_in
attributes.description: The passable height of the edge at the point where it is the shortest. Measured in inches and rounded to the nearest inch. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: width_min_passable_in
attributes.description: The passable width of the edge at the point where it is narrowest. Measured in inches and rounded to the nearest inch. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: width_tolerance_in
attributes.description: Used to specify the tolerance of the width measurement in inches. Everything along the edge should be within +/- of this width.

attributes.name: bridge
attributes.description: Indicates if the edge is or is on a bridge. Can be used for any bridge type, including road bridges (with or without bike lanes) and pedestrian and bike bridges.

attributes.name: underpass_tunnel
attributes.description: Indicates that the edge represents an underground path, such as a tunnel or an underpass.

attributes.name: overpass_skywalk
attributes.description: Indicates that the edge represents a skywalk, pedestrian or bicycle overpass, or other elevated infrastructure that is not a bridge.

attributes.name: above_below_grade_ft
attributes.description:
Height of the path above/below grade, measured in feet and rounded to the closest foot. If below grade, provide the value as a negative number. (Ex. if the path is 10 feet above grade, this attribute would equal "10".)

For uncertain heights, use an appropriate description from the list: "above", "below", "at grade"

attributes.name: building_level
attributes.description:
Level of the building or structure the path is on, as labelled for users inside the building. 

Intended to capture the fact that often floor 1 isn't the level at-grade and sometimes buildings skip floors or label below-grade floors "B" or "SB".

attributes.name: status
attributes.description: Most recent operating status of the segment. Whether the infrastructure is open and available for use. If left blank, status is assumed "unknown."

attributes.name: date_built
attributes.description:
When the facility was officially opened for use. date_built represents the original opening date. Use the Events extension to record details about construction history, remodeling, removal and other physical changes.

Report in RFC 3339 format containing day, month and year, or just month and year or year if day or month is not available.

attributes.name: last_inspection_date
attributes.description: The date that this infrastructure was last inspected. Report in RFC 3339 format containing day, month and year, or just month and year or year if day or month is not available.

attributes.name: curb_height_in
attributes.description: Indicates typical height of the curb along this segment of the road; can be used in deciding whether to route specific pedestrians off the sidewalk when there are obstructions or discontinuities. Measured and rounded to the nearest inch. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: official
attributes.description: Indicates whether a trail has been officially designated by a government body or other recognized organization, with a string of the name of the recognizing body and/or a URL to the source/reference to the recognition for users to verify and see additional information. If not an official trail, the value should be "no." If left blank, the trail is assumed official and managed by a local government agency.

attributes.name: presence
attributes.description: Indicates whether the piece of infrastructure exists or is present. When other attributes are provided, the existence of the infrastructure can be assumed. This attribute is useful for identifying where a sidewalk or a crossing might be missing or where its presence is unknown. Conditionally required if no other identfiying fields supplied.

attributes.name: measured_length_ft
attributes.description:
The measured length of the edge in feet. Represent partial feet using decimals.

Note that geospatial data also contains a length attribute by default that may be useful in some cases. Measuring the traversable length of the segment is preferable.

attributes.name: bikeway_type
attributes.description: Common name used for the bicycle facility type. Should align with the National Bikeway Network, NACTO, or AASHTO facility types.

attributes.name: bikeway_grade_separation
attributes.description: The vertical level of the bikeway with respect to the road. Not meant for bikeways that are not road associated.

attributes.name: separation_elements
attributes.description: The materials used to separate the cycleway or footway from motor vehicle traffic -- for example, as part of a buffer.

attributes.name: separation_permeable_car
attributes.description: Whether a motor vehicle can easily access this edge. Primarily intended for bikeways but can be used for pedestrian facilities.
listed_values: hard separator:  the separator cannot be easily bypassed by motor vehicles (jersey barriers
soft separator: the separator can be easily bypassed by motor vehicles (flex posts
none: no separator is present (just paint separation)

attributes.name: buffer_width_ft
attributes.description: Distance between the edge of the motor vehicle travel lane and the bike lane or sidewalk. Measured in feet, with partial feet represented using decimals. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: street_parking
attributes.description: Indicates the orientation of street parking in relation to a bike facility. The value "floating" means the same as "parking protected."
listed_values: floating: Also known as parking protected. Put this value if present regardless if parking is parallel/angled parking.

attributes.name: street_parking_buffer_ft
attributes.description: The space between a bicycle facility and the street parking. Measured in feet, with partial feet represented as decimals. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: wheel_channel
attributes.description: Whether there is a wheel channel to allow for pushing a bicycle up the stairs.

attributes.name: traffic_volume
attributes.description: Measures the motor vehicle annual average daily traffic (AADT) for the edge. Ideally rounded to the nearest hundred for low-volume roads and the nearest thousand for high-volume roads. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: posted_speed_limit_mph
attributes.description: Used to indicate the posted speed limit. Measured in miles per hour. Cannot be negative. If used on bikeway, multi-use path, or trail, it's assumed that is the speed limit for non-motorized users.

attributes.name: mv_freeflow_speed_mph
attributes.description: Used to indicate the free-flow motor vehicle speed. Suggest using the 85th percentile. Measured in miles per hour. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: thru_lanes
attributes.description: Describes the number of vehicle thru lanes on an edge. Does not include turn lanes or shoulders. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: aux_lanes
attributes.description: Describes the number of temporary vehicle lanes like turn lanes. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: shoulder_width_in
attributes.description: Width of the paved shoulder or shoulders along the edge that can be used by pedestrians or cyclists. Measured in inches. Cannot be negative. Left/right/both tags may be used, and the directionality is determined based on how the edge geometry was drawn. See Directionality and Left/Right/Both Tags in the GATIS Playbook for further explanation.

attributes.name: markings
attributes.description: Markings that delineate or mark the area of the road or other edge for bicyclists or pedestrians, or for motor vehicle driver awareness of bike and pedestrian infrastructure or space. Left/right/both tagging may be used. See the Playbook for more information on this tagging.

attributes.name: roadway_centerline
attributes.description: Indicates if there is a painted road centerline. This attribute is sometimes used to help identify low-stress streets.

attributes.name: mup_modal_delineation
attributes.description: Designates whether bicyclists and pedestrians have separate designated spaces on a multi-use path, or whether all travelers use the same space.

attributes.name: prohibited_uses
attributes.description: Specifies which types of users are legally prohibited from using the facility, based on the laws, policy, or signage on a facility (ex. “E-bikes prohibited on this trail”). Can provide one or multiple in list form.
listed_values: motor_vehicle ebike class 2 ebike class 3 other

attributes.name: allowed_uses
attributes.description: Specifies exceptions to the usually prohibited users. Intended for designating whether bikes are allowed to use sidewalks, footways, and crossings for routing purposes.
listed_values: motor_vehicle ebike class 2 ebike class 3 other
attributes.example: Bicycles normally prohibited from using the sidewalk but the sidewalk is a critical edge for connectivity.

attributes.name: restricted_access
attributes.description: Whether access to the edge is restricted based on membership, passes / permits or access codes. Meant to help travelers easily know if general access is not allowed.

attributes.name: vehicle_traffic_control
attributes.description: Describes how motor vehicle traffic that passes through the crossing edge is controlled. In an intersection where two roads cross, the road that is perpendicular to the crossing edge would be described using this attribute. Use cross_vehicle_traffic_control to describe the road that is parallel to the crossing edge.

attributes.name: cross_vehicle_traffic_control
attributes.description: Describes how motor vehicle traffic coming from cross streets is controlled. This traffic may or may not turn into the crossing space. In an intersection where two roads cross, the road that is parallel to the crossing edge would be described using this attribute. Use vehicle_traffic_control to describe the road that is perpendicular to the crossing edge. For intersections with more than one cross street, list all of the control types present for all of the cross streets in this attribute.

attributes.name: ped_traffic_control
attributes.description: Describes the type of signal that controls pedestrian use of the crossing. If left blank, "unknown" is assumed.

attributes.name: ped_protection
attributes.description: Any features of traffic control that are intended to improve the protection of pedestrians while crossing. List all that are present. If left blank, "unknown" is assumed.
listed_values: no right on red for motor vehicles

attributes.name: traffic_calming
attributes.description: Used to identify features along a road or crossing meant to slow the speed of motor vehicle traffic when that feature is present alongside the entirety or majority of the edge. Most traffic calming features are better mapped as zones or points, due to their shape and placement. Please see the traffic_calming zone and point types to map other types of traffic calming. The attributes that the traffic calming element(s) affect should be modified -- for example, a road narrowing should reduce the road's width attribute to match the narrowed width. Recommended values are from https://www.ite.org/technical-resources/traffic-calming/traffic-calming-measures/ and https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:traffic_calming.

attributes.name: seasonal
attributes.description: Indicates whether the segment is commonly affected by seasonal issues. Use this field for recurring (ex. yearly flooding) and not one-time (ex. single flood) events. Include both the seasonal concern and the season when it occurs as a JSON String.

attributes.name: surface_material
attributes.description: Specifies the material used for the surface of the segment.

attributes.name: surface_issue
attributes.description: Description of surface quality issues that may pose a challenge for travelers passing along this edge.

attributes.name: pedestrian_lane
attributes.description: Indicates whether the stretch of sidewalk is a pedestrian lane, in which a section of the roadway surface is divided out for pedestrian use.

attributes.name: incline
attributes.description: The running slope of the full edge. The incline should follow the direction in which the geospatial feature was drawn. If the incline increases between the from_node and the to_node, it should be positive. If the incline decreases between the from_node and the to_node, it should be negative. Report as a percentage with two decimal points of precision. See the Playbook for more information on directionality.

attributes.name: cross_slope
attributes.description: The cross slope of the edge at most points along its path. Report as percentage with two decimal points of precision. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: cross_slope_max
attributes.description: The cross slope of the edge at the point along its path where there is the greatest cross slope. Report as a percentage with two decimal points of precision. Cannot be negative.

attributes.name: ada_compliance_date
attributes.description: Indicates the date when ADA compliance was assessed. Report in RFC 3339 format containing day, month and year, or just month and year or year if day or month is not available.. This field is conditionally required if "ada_compliant_with" is filled out.

attributes.name: ada_compliant_with
attributes.description: If this infrastructure has been assessed for ADA compliance, the specific ADA guidelines or standards used in the assessment. Also fill out "ada_compliance_date." If no ADA assessment is being reported, leave blank.

attributes.name: impediment
attributes.description: Identifies the presence of an object that may pose a challenge for travelers passing along this edge. Mark an edge with this attribute only if the impediment is close enough to the footway/pedestrian way or bike path to potentially pose a challenge. If left blank, the assumed value for this attribute is “unknown.”

attributes.name: step_count
attributes.description: The number of steps that make up this set of stairs. Must be greater than zero.

attributes.name: handrail
attributes.description: Whether a handrail is available on this set of stairs.

attributes.name: rail_crossing
attributes.description: Used to indicate if a pedestrian or bicycle crossing is a railroad crossing. Use generic nodes to connect a rail crossing to the rest of the network. Note that there is also a value of "rail tracks" for the other_issue attribute for edges. Use this attribute for track crossings that people walking, rolling or biking will need to cross, and that have active rail traffic. The "rail tracks" value for other_issue can be used on other edge types or to identify remaining or unused tracks no longer traveled by trains.

attributes.name: visual_markings
attributes.description: The way the crossing is marked within the roadway space. See the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (https://mutcd.fhwa.dot.gov/pdfs/11th_Edition/part3.pdf) Chapter 3C and Figure 3C-1 for more information. This attribute can accept a list of values. Include all that apply.

attributes.name: tactile_marking
attributes.description: Indicates when tactile guidestrips or other markings are present to help identify the edge of a crosswalk or traffic island, the beginning or end of steps, or the presence of other infrastructure nearby, such as bike lanes. It is recommended to segment the edge so that this field is only equal to “yes” for the segment where the detectable warning appears. Do not use this field for tactile markings on curb ramps; instead, use the detectable_warning attribute for curb_ramp nodes in Tiers 1 and 2, and the detectable_warning attribute for the curb_ramp_runslope and curb_ramp_toplanding edges in Tiers 3 and 4.

attributes.name: other_issue
attributes.description: Identifies whether this edge has another type of issue that may pose a challenge for travelers, besides impediments and surface damage. Includes design, construction and other issue types. Note that there is also an attribute for rail_crossing, which indicates if a crossing edge is a rail crossing. Use rail_crossing for track crossings that people walking, rolling or biking will need to cross, and that have active rail traffic. The "rail tracks" value here can be used on other edge types or to identify remaining or unused tracks no longer traveled by trains.
listed_values: detectable warning not aligned with crossing

attributes.name: lrs_references
attributes.description: A JSON list capturing the attributes that appear in the GATIS LRS extension. See the extension for full attribute descriptions. Either this attribute or the extension may be used based on which is more convenient for the data producer and likely users. This attribute should be placed on each separate piece of infrastructure that is being mapped to LRS, with its specific milepoints.

attributes.name: last_inspection_type
attributes.description: The type of inspection that was carried out on the piece of infrastructure, on the date listed under last_inspection_date.

attributes.name: lifecycle_stage
attributes.description: The lifecycle stage of this piece of infrastructure, as of the last_inspection_date.

attributes.name: maintenance_schedule
attributes.description: Description of the maintenance schedule, frequency of inspection, replacement schedule or other information about when the piece of infrastructure is maintained.

attributes.name: planned_work
attributes.description: Description of any planned work ahead for the infrastructure. This may include plans for construction or remodeling, upcoming work orders or other types of planned improvements.

attributes.name: owner
attributes.description: The entity that owns this piece of infrastructure. If a department, office or subagency is responsible for the infrastructure, list that department, office or subagency.

attributes.name: maintainer
attributes.description: The entity that is responsible for maintaining this piece of infrastructure. It may or may not be the same as owner. If a department, office or subagency is responsible for the infrastructure, list that department, office or subagency.

attributes.name: lighting
attributes.description: Whether or not this edge has lighting along its entirety or majority. For single points where lighting appears, use the object point type with object_type = lighting. For enhanced lighting of crosswalks, see the ped_protection attribute on the crossing edge.

attributes.name: bike_dismount_area
attributes.description: Whether this edge contains an area where cyclists are asked to dismount from their cycles.

attributes.name: detectable_warning
attributes.description: Describes whether tactile paving is present, and whether or not it has a constrasting color (which should meet ADA guidelines for the amount of contrast).

attributes.name: ramp_type
attributes.description: Indicates the orientation of the ramp in relation to the pedestrian direction of travel at the location. Where a double curb ramp exists, map each ramp as a separate curb_ramp_runslope.

attributes.name: ramp_length
attributes.description: Indicates the length of the incline portion of the curb ramp.
